title: Downgrading a Pledged Animal for a Youth Program
vignette: A farmer promised his best unblemished ewe-lamb to a youth-ag program, then tries to swap in a scarred one instead. Is this acceptable?

options.text: Reject the substitution; the original animal remains designated, and the lesser one may also become designated as a penalty.
Allow the swap since both animals belong to him.

title: Regret After Authorizing a Substitute Donation
vignette: Moments after authorizing a replacement animal for a charity auction, the owner has second thoughts and asks to cancel the switch. Can officials void it?

options.text: Too lateâ€”the substitution is legally binding once declared.
Permit the annulment due to a hasty, unconsidered statement.

title: Program Official Misuses a Designated Animal
vignette: A program official exchanges a designated charity ram for a similar one from his own flock and keeps the designated one for a private party.

options.text: He must return the designated animal and be sanctioned for misuse of assets.
No harm done if an animal of equal value remains designated for the charity.

title: Attempting a Second Substitution for a Designated Animal
vignette: After one legal replacement of a designated animal, the owner proposes swapping the new animal yet again for a different one. Does the second switch count?

options.text: Only the first exchange takes effect. Subsequent swaps are invalid.
Each successful swap creates an additional designated animal.

title: Unauthorized Substitution by a Family Member
vignette: While feeding the herd, a teenager proclaims a substitute for his father's bull that was pledged to a breeding program. Is this statement binding on the father?

options.text: It is void because the teenager lacks the legal authority to manage the assets.
It should be counted since he spoke sincerely on behalf of the family farm.

title: Substituting a Communal Donation
vignette: Members of a town cooperative attempt to exchange their communally-owned prize bull, already designated for a national competition, for a nicer one.

options.text: Communally-owned designated assets cannot be swapped.
Allow it, to improve the community's chances in the competition.

title: Attempting to Upgrade a Pledged Animal
vignette: A donor buys a stronger bull months after pledging the first one to a charity auction. He now wants the new one to carry the pledge. Does the original remain pledged as well?

options.text: Yes, the new bull also becomes designated for the auction in addition to the first one.
Only the replacement animal becomes designated.

title: Accidental Swap of Designated Animals Between Two Donors
vignette: Two neighbors accidentally swap animals that each had committed to separate agricultural charities. Should the charities cancel the exchanges to avoid confusion?

options.text: Both exchanges are binding, creating additional designated animals for each charity.
Cancel the swaps to avoid the administrative chaos.

title: Status of Offspring from a Substituted Animal
vignette: A calf is born from a cow that was substituted for an originally pledged animal. Does the calf also have a designated status?

options.text: Yes, the offspring is also considered designated.
Only the mother retains the designated status.

title: Invalid Cross-Species Substitution
vignette: An owner tries to replace a pledged steer with a goat of equal market value for a breeding program. Is a cross-species swap valid?

options.text: Invalid swap; the program requires a steer.
Accept the goat of equal value to fulfill the pledge.

title: Ambiguous Substitution Declaration
vignette: Witnesses hear an owner mumble a replacement declaration for a pledged animal but can't tell which of his other animals he meant. Does any substitution take effect?

options.text: Without a clear and unambiguous declaration, it has no legal effect.
Assume a valid intent and apply the substitution to the most likely animal.

title: Substitution Attempt by a Non-Member
vignette: A visiting farmer, who is not a member of the breed association, offers to substitute his animal for a member's designated prize bull.

options.text: Disallow; the substitution rule applies only to animals owned by association members.
Permit the substitution if the member agrees.

title: Substituting a Superior Animal for Financial Gain
vignette: An owner pledges a heifer to a charity, then substitutes a pricier one so he can sell the first for profit. Do both now count as pledged stock?

options.text: Both animals become designated and cannot be sold freely for personal gain.
Allow the sale of one to fund the charity.

title: Effect of an Invalid Cross-Species Swap
vignette: An ox designated for a program is swapped for a goat. The rules forbid cross-species swaps. Does the goat also become designated as a penalty for the attempt, or does the invalidity of the swap mean nothing happens?

options.text: The goat also becomes designated, in addition to the ox, as a penalty for the attempted illicit exchange.
The substitution fails completely because the species differ; nothing happens.

title: Error Discovered After Donated Animal is Processed
vignette: Only after the charity has processed the meat from a substituted animal does the owner realize he made an improper substitution.

options.text: The donation counts, though it was improper.
It is invalid; a new, proper donation is required.
